IPv6 also includes additional features, such as improved security and network auto-configuration. Although IPv6 has been available for many years, the adoption has been relatively slow. This is due to several factors, including the complexity of transitioning from IPv4 to IPv6 and the fact that IPv4 is still widely used and supported. However, as the demand for IP addresses continues to increase, the transition to IPv6 is becoming more necessary, and many organizations and internet service providers are gradually making the switch.

An ISP is a company that provides internet access and related services to individuals and organizations. They connect customers to the internet and manage the infrastructure and equipment necessary for reliable internet access. ISPs charge customers a fee for their services, and there are many different providers operating worldwide.

Java applets are small programs written in the Java programming language that can be embedded into web pages and run by web browsers. They can perform a variety of tasks but have declined in popularity due to security concerns and the rise of other web technologies.

The Java sandbox is a security feature that restricts the actions of untrusted or potentially malicious code running within the Java Virtual Machine (JVM). It limits the code's access to system resources and prevents it from consuming excessive resources, providing a secure environment for executing untrusted code.

JavaScript is a programming language used for creating interactive and dynamic web pages, as well as for other applications such as mobile app development and game development. It runs on the client-side of the web and is executed by web browsers, allowing for real-time updates and interactivity on web pages.

Keystroke monitoring is the process of tracking and recording the keys that are pressed on a computer keyboard, usually for monitoring employee activity or detecting unauthorized access to computer systems. It can be performed using hardware or software-based methods but is controversial due to privacy concerns and the potential for unethical use.

A logic bomb is a type of malicious code or software that is intentionally inserted into a computer system to perform a specific action or cause damage at a predetermined time or under specific conditions. Logic bombs can be programmed to execute when certain conditions are met, such as when a specific date or time is reached, when a certain program is executed, or when a specific user performs a certain action. The purpose of a logic bomb is often to cause damage or disrupt normal system operations, such as by deleting files, corrupting data, or shutting down critical services. Logic bombs can be difficult to detect and prevent, as they can be designed to lie dormant for long periods of time before executing. Logic bombs are illegal and considered a serious threat to computer security. They are often used by hackers, disgruntled employees, or other malicious actors to cause damage or gain unauthorized access to computer systems. Preventative measures against logic bombs include regularly updating system software and monitoring system activity for suspicious behavior.

The Master Boot Record (MBR) is a piece of code at the beginning of a hard disk that initiates the boot process and contains information about the disk's partition table and boot loader. It can be vulnerable to malware attacks, and preventative measures such as antivirus software and backups are recommended.

Moore's Law states that the number of transistors on a microchip will double every two years while the cost of producing these chips will decrease, leading to a rapid increase in computing power and a decrease in the cost of electronics. It has been a driving force behind technology advancement and the development of new technologies, but its future is uncertain due to physical and economic limitations.

Open source in computer science refers to software that is made freely available to the public, with its source code included, allowing anyone to view, modify, and distribute it. It is often created and maintained by a community of developers and has benefits such as transparency, flexibility, and accessibility. It is widely used in various applications.

An operating system (OS) is a software program that manages computer hardware and software resources, providing an interface for users to interact with the computer and run applications. It manages system resources, provides security features, and manages system updates and software installations. Examples include Windows, macOS, Linux, and Android.

Parallel processing is a type of computing in which multiple processors or cores work together to execute a task simultaneously, allowing for faster processing and greater efficiency. It's commonly used in scientific simulations, data analytics, and multimedia processing. There are two main types: shared memory and distributed memory. Parallel processing is becoming increasingly important in the age of big data and complex computational tasks.

A computer password is a sequence of characters used to authenticate a user and grant access to a computer or system. They help prevent unauthorized access and are required for logging in to a computer, user account, network, or application. Strong passwords should be unique, complex, and regularly changed. Passwords are a fundamental component of computer security.

Ubiquitous computing, also known as pervasive computing, is a concept in computer science in which computing and communication technologies are seamlessly integrated into everyday objects and environments, allowing for constant and pervasive access to information and communication. The goal of ubiquitous computing is to create a world where technology is so seamlessly integrated into our surroundings that it becomes invisible and ubiquitous. This can be achieved through the use of sensors, wireless communication, and the internet of things (IoT), which allows objects to communicate with each other and with the internet. Examples of ubiquitous computing include smart homes, wearables, and smart cities, where objects and systems are interconnected and can communicate with each other to provide personalized and context-aware services. Overall, ubiquitous computing aims to create a world where technology is seamlessly integrated into our everyday lives, enhancing our experiences and making our environments more efficient, convenient, and personalized.

PHP is a server-side scripting language used primarily for web development. It's designed to create dynamic web pages and applications and can be embedded into HTML code. PHP code is executed on the server side, which means that the output of the code is sent to the web browser in the form of HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. PHP can be used to perform various tasks such as handling forms, processing user input, interacting with databases, and generating dynamic content. PHP is open-source software, meaning that it's free to use and modify, and is supported by a large community of developers who contribute to its development and provide support and resources for users. It's widely used by web developers for building websites and web applications and is compatible with most web servers and operating systems. Overall, PHP is a popular and powerful scripting language for web development, with a wide range of applications and a large community of users and developers.

Ping is a computer network utility used to test the connectivity and response time of network devices. It sends a packet of data to a specific IP address or hostname and measures the round-trip time it takes for the data to travel between two devices. It's commonly used for network troubleshooting and monitoring.

Port Address Translation (PAT), also known as Network Address Port Translation (NAPT), is a technique used in computer networking to allow multiple devices on a private network to share a single public IP address. PAT works by assigning a unique port number to each device on the private network, allowing the router to keep track of which device is associated with each incoming or outgoing connection. When a device on the private network initiates a connection to the internet, the router replaces the private IP address of the device with the public IP address of the router and uses the unique port number to identify the device. PAT is commonly used in small office or home networks, where a limited number of public IP addresses are available, and multiple devices need to access the internet simultaneously. It's also used by internet service providers (ISPs) to conserve public IP addresses and manage network traffic. Overall, PAT is a useful technique for managing network resources and allowing multiple devices to share a single public IP address.

Port scanning is a technique used to discover open ports and services on a computer or network device. A port is a communication endpoint in a network device, and each service or application running on the device typically uses a specific port to communicate with other devices on the network. Port scanning works by sending a series of network packets to a target device, with each packet attempting to establish a connection on a different port. If a connection is successful, the scanner can determine the port status (open, closed, or filtered) and potentially identify the service or application running on the port. Port scanning can be used for legitimate purposes, such as network management and security testing, but it can also be used for malicious activities, such as identifying vulnerable services or attempting to gain unauthorized access to a network. Network administrators and security professionals often use port scanning tools to identify open ports and services on their own networks and to detect and prevent port scanning attempts by unauthorized users.

Pretty Good Privacy (PGP) is an encryption software used to secure emails, files, and other forms of digital communication. It uses a combination of symmetric-key and public-key cryptography to encrypt and decrypt messages and provides digital signature functionality for verifying message authenticity and integrity. It was developed by Phil Zimmermann in 1991 as a free, open-source solution for secure communication over the internet.

In computer science, a protocol refers to a set of rules and procedures that dictate how data is transmitted over a network. Protocols ensure that devices and systems can communicate with each other effectively and efficiently, even if they are made by different manufacturers or use different operating systems. A protocol defines the format and structure of data packets, as well as the order and timing of their transmission. It also specifies how errors and other issues should be handled and what actions should be taken in the event of a problem. There are many different protocols used in computer networks, ranging from low-level protocols such as Ethernet and TCP/IP to application-level protocols such as HTTP and FTP. Each protocol has its own specific purpose and functionality, and they work together to create a seamless and reliable communication network.

Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) is a technology that uses radio waves to wirelessly identify and track objects or people. RFID systems consist of three main components: a tag or transponder, a reader or interrogator, and a backend system for processing the data. The RFID tag contains a small microchip and an antenna, which can be attached to or embedded within an object. When the tag is exposed to radio waves from a nearby reader, it powers up and sends back a signal containing its unique identifier. RFID technology has a wide range of applications, from tracking inventory and assets

Remote Access Tools (RATs) are software allowing remote control of computers over a network. While they have legitimate uses, hackers exploit them for unauthorized access, leading to data theft or malware installation. Vigilance, reputable antivirus software, and regular updates help guard against RATs.

The Rijndael algorithm, adopted as the Advanced Encryption Standard (AES) in 2001, secures digital data. Operating on 128-bit blocks, it supports key sizes of 128, 192, or 256 bits. Employing mathematical operations like substitution and XOR, Rijndael transforms plaintext into ciphertext. It finds application in secure communication, digital rights management, and software like Adobe Acrobat.

Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) restricts computer resource access based on user roles. Administrators assign roles linked to specific privileges, streamlining access management. For instance, in a hospital, RBAC ensures doctors access relevant patient records, enhancing security, administration, and regulatory compliance.

A network router forwards data packets between computer networks, connecting devices. Operating at the network layer, routers use routing tables to determine the best data path. They come with various features like firewalls and VPN support, serving as central connectivity points in home or business networks.

Script kiddies are novice hackers using pre-made tools for attacks. Lacking coding skills, they seek recognition through activities like website defacement. Despite being a nuisance, their actions can still cause damage.

A hard disk sector is a small storage unit, typically 512 bytes or 4 kilobytes. Sectors, organized into tracks on a disk's surface, determine storage capacity. Modern hard disks may have larger sector sizes.
A secure hash, like SHA-256 or MD5, is a cryptographic function generating a fixed-size output from input data. It ensures message integrity, digital signatures, and secure password storage.

Secure Socket Layer (SSL) establishes encrypted links between clients and servers for secure data transmission. SSL, succeeded by Transport Layer Security (TLS), uses both symmetric and asymmetric encryption.

Signature-based intrusion detection systems (IDS) identify known security threats by matching patterns or signatures in network traffic. While effective against known attacks, they may miss new threats, necessitating additional security measures.
Smurfing floods a network with ICMP echo requests, often in DDoS attacks. Filtering incoming traffic and blocking broadcast traffic can mitigate smurfing.
A sniffer software captures and analyzes data packets on a network for monitoring or malicious purposes.
Social engineering manipulates individuals to divulge sensitive information or perform unauthorized actions, employing tactics like deception and persuasion.
P2P spoofing disguises malicious traffic as legitimate peer-to-peer traffic in a network. Attackers mimic legitimate users for activities like malware distribution, making detection challenging.

Steganography is a clever way of hiding messages within other files, images, or texts. Think of it as a secret code hidden in plain sight, accessible only to those who know the trick to find it. It's like a digital game of hide and seek, where the hidden message is often encrypted for extra secrecy. Unlike cryptography, which scrambles a message to make it unreadable, steganography is all about stealth - keeping the existence of the message itself a secret.

Imagine a stream cipher as a secret agent of the digital world, working one bit or byte at a time. It takes ordinary text and, using a key like a series of random puzzle pieces, transforms it into a secret code. Unlike its cousin, the block cipher, which works in chunks, a stream cipher flows continuously, making it perfect for live broadcasts or chatting online. But beware – if the key falls into the wrong hands or if the code isn't random enough, the secret might be out!

Picture e-government as a digital makeover for government services, where the internet, smartphones, and other tech tools come together to make dealing with the government easier and faster. It's like having a government office at your fingertips – you can fill out forms, find information, and even vote online. This digital shift not only makes life more convenient but also opens up new ways for citizens to have a say in their government. It's a modern twist on democracy, using technology to bring people and their governments closer.

Named after the engineer behind the iconic Eiffel Tower, the Eiffel programming language is a masterclass in elegance and efficiency. Created in the 1980s, it's like a Swiss Army knife for software developers, with tools for designing robust and error-free software. Eiffel emphasizes clarity and reliability, making it a go-to choice for critical systems in aerospace or finance, where a single error could be costly. It's not just a language; it's a philosophy of creating dependable and maintainable software.

Eiffel isn't just a language; it's a versatile tool used across various industries and academic fields. In the commercial sector, it's crafting software for finance and healthcare, while in academia, it's a lab tool for exploring the frontiers of programming. Open source projects bring Eiffel to the masses, showcasing its strengths in creating reliable and secure software. Whether it's guiding airplanes safely or managing your health records, Eiffel is the unseen hero ensuring everything runs smoothly.

Electronic voting systems come in three flavors. First, there's the Direct Recording Electronic system, kind of like a digital ballot box where you press a button or touch a screen to cast your vote. Then, there's the Optical Scan system, where you mark a paper ballot and a machine tallies your vote like a high-tech vote counter. Finally, there's Remote Electronic Voting, where you can vote from your couch using a computer, with high-tech security to keep your vote safe and secret.

Early voting is like an RSVP for elections – it lets you cast your vote ahead of the big day. Whether you're busy or out of town on election day, early voting has you covered with options like mail-in ballots or designated polling stations. It's all about making voting as convenient as a trip to the grocery store, reducing those long lines and ensuring everyone gets a chance to participate. While it's a logistical jigsaw for the authorities, it's a win for democracy and voter turnout.

Touch screens have transformed how we interact with our gadgets. They come in various types, each with its own touch-detecting wizardry. There's the resistive screen, feeling your touch through pressure, like a gentle push. The capacitive screen senses the touch of your finger by changes in electrical fields, like a magic touch. Infrared screens detect touch by interruptions in a light field, like an invisible dance of fingers and light. And then there are Surface Acoustic Wave screens, using sound waves to pinpoint your touch, almost like echolocation.

Optical scan technology is like having an electronic eye that reads paper marks. In voting, it's the tech behind those paper ballots where you fill in bubbles, and a machine tallies your vote with speed and accuracy. But it's not just for elections – think of surveys, tests, or any paper form that needs quick, error-free processing. It's a bridge between the paper world and the digital, bringing the ease of electronic analysis to the tactile world of paper.

Email, short for electronic mail, is the digital age's pen pal system. It's a quick, convenient way to send messages across the internet. Whether it's a simple hello, an important document, or a photo,

Embedded systems are like the unsung heroes of the digital world. They're specialized computer systems, seamlessly integrated into larger devices to perform specific tasks, from powering your car's dashboard to running your smartwatch. Unlike general-purpose computers, which are designed to be all-rounders, embedded systems are finely tuned to excel at particular functions, be it speed, energy efficiency, or reliability. You'll find them embedded in a myriad of gadgets and machines, silently running the show behind the scenes.

Emulation is like a digital chameleon, transforming one computer system to mimic another. It's all about running software or hardware meant for one system on a completely different setup. This digital impersonation is done by emulators, special software that replicates the behavior of the original system. While it's a clever way to keep old software alive on new machines or for testing, it can be a bit like a high-performance car – it needs a lot of resources to run smoothly.

Encapsulation in object-oriented programming (OOP) is like a protective bubble around an object's inner workings. It keeps an object's data safe and hidden from the outside world, revealing only what's necessary. Think of it as a privacy filter for your code – it controls who gets to see or change what's inside. This not only keeps data safe but also makes sure changes are made in a controlled way, maintaining the integrity of the program.

Encryption is the art of secret communication in the digital world. It transforms readable data into a mysterious code, accessible only to those with the secret key. It's like sending a coded letter where only the recipient knows how to decipher it, keeping sensitive information like personal details or confidential messages safe from prying eyes. In the ever-evolving digital landscape, encryption is the bodyguard for your data's privacy and security.

Enterprise computing is like the backbone of big organizations. It's the use of tech to streamline and enhance operations, from managing finances to customer relationships. Imagine a toolbox filled with digital tools – ERP systems organizing business processes, CRM systems nurturing customer relationships, and BI tools deciphering data puzzles. It's a mix of technologies and applications, all working together to make large-scale operations smoother, smarter, and more efficient.

Entrepreneurs in computing are the visionaries and innovators of the tech world. They spot opportunities and use their computing prowess to turn ideas into reality. From crafting sleek software to designing cutting-edge apps, they are at the forefront of digital transformation. These trailblazers often start with just their skills and a bold idea, building their ventures from scratch, and in doing so, they shape the future of technology and business.

Ergonomics in computing is all about creating a comfortable, safe, and efficient environment for computer users. It's like tailoring your workspace to fit you perfectly, minimizing the risk of strain or injury from long hours at the computer. From the angle of your monitor to the design of your keyboard, every detail is adjusted to promote ease and well-being, ensuring that your digital experience is not just productive but also physically harmonious.

Error correction in computing is like the proofreader of digital data, spotting and fixing mistakes in data transmission or storage. Errors can sneak in due to various glitches, but error correction codes are the guardians, adding extra bits of data to help identify and mend these errors. Techniques like Hamming code or Reed-Solomon code are the unsung heroes, ensuring the information you send or save remains accurate and reliable, a crucial safeguard in our data-dependent world.

Error handling in computing is about expecting the unexpected. It's a set of strategies to deal with errors during a program's execution, ensuring the system remains stable and usable even when things go awry. Whether it’s through informative error messages, logging for later analysis, or using try-catch statements to manage exceptions, error handling is the contingency plan that keeps a program graceful and user-friendly, even under less-than-ideal circumstances.

Expert systems in artificial intelligence are like digital consultants, mimicking the decision-making abilities of human experts. They combine a treasure trove of knowledge in a specific area with clever algorithms to analyze and solve complex problems. With a knowledge base as their foundation and an inference engine as their brain, these systems can offer advice, make predictions, or provide solutions, embodying the wisdom of experts in fields ranging from medicine to finance, all within the confines of a computer program.

Expert systems work like a brainy consultant, with two key parts: the knowledge base and the inference engine. The knowledge base is like a vast library of facts, rules, and information specific to a problem. The inference engine is the thinker – it uses this information to ponder over problems, make decisions, and offer advice. Together, they form a system that's like having an expert in a box, always ready to provide solutions and recommendations.

Data is the building block of the information age, much like atoms are to the physical world. It comes in various forms – texts, numbers, images, audio, and video – and can be stored in different ways, like in databases or spreadsheets. Data can be raw, like unpolished diamonds, or processed, refined into something more meaningful. It's either qualitative, offering descriptive insights, or quantitative, providing hard numbers. Understanding and analyzing data is like deciphering a complex puzzle, where each piece reveals a part of a larger picture.

Data abstraction is like a magician's act in programming, showing the audience only what they need to see. It simplifies complex data by hiding the nitty-gritty details and presenting only the essentials. This is like breaking down a complex machine into user-friendly controls, making software design, development, and maintenance more manageable and less overwhelming.

Using data abstraction in software development is like having a Swiss army knife; it's versatile and practical. It simplifies complexity, making large systems more manageable. It enhances modularity, keeping different parts of a system independent. Code becomes reusable, like a one-size-fits-all solution. Security improves as the inner workings are hidden away. Lastly, it makes testing and debugging easier, as problems can be isolated and fixed without affecting the entire system.

Data acquisition (DAQ) is like the five senses of a computer system, collecting information from the world. It involves gathering data from sources like sensors, converting analog signals (like our natural senses) into digital forms that computers understand. DAQ systems are like translators, turning physical phenomena into digital data, ready for analysis and decision-making.

A data acquisition system is a symphony of components working in harmony. Sensors or transducers are the front-line troops, capturing physical data. Signal conditioning is like a sound engineer, tweaking these signals for clarity. The Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) plays a pivotal role, turning analog signals into digital ones. Data storage is the library, keeping this digital information safe. Data transmission is the messenger, carrying data to its destination. The computer interface is the bridge connecting the DAQ system to computing devices, while software is the conductor, orchestrating the entire data acquisition process.

Data acquisition is a versatile tool used across various fields. In scientific research, it's like a meticulous lab assistant, gathering precise data from experiments. In industrial automation, it's the eyes and ears, monitoring production processes. For aerospace and defense, it's a vital source of information on critical systems. In the medical field, it watches over patients' vital signs, while in automotive testing, it's like a performance analyst for vehicles. And in structural health monitoring, it acts like a health inspector for buildings and bridges.

Data administration is the art of keeping an organization's data in check, ensuring it's available, secure, accurate, and accessible. It's like being the custodian of a treasure trove of information, managing it wisely to support the organization's goals. In the world where data is king, effective data administration is crucial for any organization's success.

Data security is the digital equivalent of a high-security vault, protecting valuable digital assets from unauthorized access or attacks. It's a blend of physical barriers, like locks and cameras, administrative strategies, like policies and training, and technical tools, like encryption and firewalls. In a world where data breaches can have devastating consequences, data security is the guardian angel of sensitive information.

Data integrity is the trustworthiness of data, ensuring it's accurate, complete, and consistent. It's vital for decision-making and business processes. Threats to data integrity include human errors, like typos, malicious tampering, or system glitches. Like a detective, maintaining data integrity involves vigilance and robust checks to ensure data remains pristine and reliable.

Data accessibility is about making data easy to reach and use for those who need it. It's influenced by how and where data is stored, the security measures in place, and the governance policies that dictate its use. Data integration plays a key role too, merging data from various sources into a unified, accessible format. In the information age, ensuring data is readily accessible while being securely guarded is a balancing act of great importance.

DBMS stands as the librarian of the digital world, organizing and retrieving vast amounts of data with efficiency and ease. It's like a digital filing cabinet, providing a structured way to store, manage, and access data. DBMS is the backbone of any system where large data sets need to be stored and made readily available, from customer records to inventory data, ensuring quick and efficient access.

Data communications are essential in our connected world, allowing devices like computers, smartphones, and tablets to share information. Whether it's through wired or wireless networks, satellite connections, or other means, this process keeps us interconnected, enabling seamless data exchanges across various platforms.

In the diverse realm of data communications, its applications are vast and varied. In business, it streamlines interactions across departments and facilitates remote collaborations. Education leverages it for online learning, bridging distances between students and teachers. Healthcare utilizes it for telemedicine, enhancing patient care. Financial sectors depend on it for secure online transactions, while transportation systems use it for efficient traffic management. In entertainment, it powers our streaming and social media experiences. Even government agencies employ it for public safety and services.

Data compression is a clever trick to make digital files smaller. It works by removing redundant bits from data, making it quicker to send and cheaper to store. It's like packing a suitcase – fitting more by folding things neatly. But how well this works depends on the data type and the compression method used.

Data conversion is all about flexibility, transforming data from one format to another. It's necessary when sharing information between different systems or using various applications. Whether it's turning analog signals into digital ones or switching between digital formats, data conversion ensures that information remains accessible and usable.

Imagine a dictionary, but instead of words, it's for data. That's a data dictionary. It lists every bit of data used in a system, explains what they mean, how they relate to each other, and the rules for using them. It's the go-to guide for anyone working with that data, making sure everyone's on the same page

Data mining is like a treasure hunt in the world of big data. It involves sifting through massive datasets to find hidden patterns and insights. Using sophisticated statistical methods, this process helps uncover trends that can guide business strategies and improve operations.

Data structures are the backbone of computer science, organizing data in a way that makes it easy to use and manipulate. They come in various forms, each with its own strengths. For example, arrays store elements of the same type, linked lists connect data in a sequence, trees organize data hierarchically, and graphs show connections between items. Hash tables offer quick data access, while queues and stacks manage data in specific order sequences.

There's a variety of data structures, each with its special role. Arrays line up data neatly. Linked lists connect pieces like a chain. Trees branch out data hierarchically. Graphs show how different points are interlinked. Hash tables are the fast-track to finding data. Queues and stacks manage data in a tidy, orderly fashion

Structured data types are the building blocks for storing complex information. Arrays hold elements of the same kind, while structures group different types under one roof. Classes are like upgraded structures with extra perks. Records keep tabs on different data types together, and enumerations are like a list of fixed values. Pointers, well, they point to where the data lives.

A data warehouse is a giant library for a company's data, designed to help make smart business decisions. It gathers, organizes, and stores information from everywhere - sales records, external data, you name it. It's set up for easy searching and analysis, aiming to uncover hidden patterns and insights that aren't obvious at first glance.

A Decision Support System (DSS) is like a digital advisor for tough decisions. It combines data, user-friendly interfaces, and smart analysis tools. Whether it's financial planning, managing stock, or figuring out the best marketing strategy, a DSS helps break down complex problems using data, making decision-making a bit easier.

Dell started as a small venture in Michael Dell's dorm room at the University of Texas at Austin in 1984, where he sold computer parts. It has since grown into a global tech giant, operating in over 180 countries with over 165,000 employees. Dell's product range spans from personal computers to complex server systems, offering tailored solutions and direct sales to customers' doorsteps

In the computing world, a demon (or daemon) is like an unseen helper, working tirelessly in the background. These programs handle tasks from managing resources to overseeing system performance, all without needing a human to direct them. They're the unsung heroes of operating systems and networks, always ready to respond to specific requests or carry out essential maintenance.

Design patterns are the blueprints of software design, offering tried-and-tested solutions for common problems faced during development. The 'Gang of Four' introduced these concepts in their 1990s book, categorizing them into creational, structural, and behavioral patterns. These patterns help developers communicate ideas and build flexible, efficient software.

Patterns in software engineering are like the golden rules for solving recurring design dilemmas. They guide developers in creating scalable, efficient software, categorized into creational, structural, and behavioral types. Each category, with patterns like Singleton or Observer, addresses different aspects of software design, from object creation to inter-object communication.

Desktop publishing revolutionized the way we create visual documents. Using specialized software, designers craft everything from brochures to books with greater control over layout, text, and graphics. This approach gives a creative edge over traditional typesetting, allowing for a diverse range of styles and formats.

Device drivers are the translators between your computer's operating system and its hardware, like printers or graphics cards. They ensure that when you connect a new device, your computer knows how to communicate with it, translating commands into actions. Keeping these drivers updated is key to smooth performance and compatibility.

Digital cash, or e-cash, is the invisible money that powers online transactions. It's a secure, digital version of real-world currency used for online purchases and transfers. Operating through digital wallets and encrypted transactions, it offers the convenience of digital transactions without the need for physical cash or cards.

Digital convergence is the blending of various technologies into one seamless experience. It's evident in smartphones, which combine communication, internet, and entertainment, or in smart homes, where security, automation, and entertainment systems work together. This convergence is reshaping how we interact with technology in our daily lives.

A digital dashboard is like the control center for business data. It displays key metrics and performance indicators in one easy-to-view interface, helping managers and executives stay informed. Customizable to display various data visualizations, it simplifies complex information into digestible, actionable insights.

The digital divide is a modern chasm, separating those with access to digital technologies and the internet from those without. This gap can lead to disparities in education, employment, and essential services, widening socio-economic differences and hindering growth in affected communities.

Digital Rights Management (DRM) is the guardian of digital content. It uses encryption and other measures to prevent unauthorized use of digital media like music, videos, or e-books. While DRM helps ensure creators get their due, it's a balancing act, as it can also restrict how users legitimately access and use content.

Distributed computing is like a virtual team of computers, each lending a hand to solve big, complex problems. They're connected over a network, combining their processing powers. This approach is used for tasks ranging from scientific research to large-scale simulations, like analyzing vast datasets or modeling physical systems.

Distributed computing plays a vital role in various fields. In science, it powers large-scale simulations and data analysis. Projects like SETI@home and Folding@home are great examples, searching for extraterrestrial life and understanding protein folding. It's also key in big data analytics, using platforms like Hadoop and Spark for processing huge datasets. In cloud computing, services like AWS and Azure offer resources on demand. And for content delivery, it's used to efficiently distribute web content globally.

The Domain Name System, or DNS, is the internet's way of translating friendly domain names into IP addresses, the numerical labels computers use to find each other online. When you type a website's name, DNS servers jump into action to find the right IP address, connecting you to your destination. It's a vast, distributed network, ensuring smooth and efficient internet browsing.

The Document Object Model (DOM) is like a blueprint of a web page, showing each element - like text and images - as parts of a tree. Developers use languages like JavaScript to interact with the DOM, allowing them to make web pages dynamic and responsive to user actions. This is what makes web applications interactive and engaging.

Digital Subscriber Line (DSL) is a type of internet connection that cleverly uses existing telephone lines. It splits the line into two channels: one for phone calls and another for internet, allowing you to use both simultaneously. With DSL, high-speed internet access is made possible without needing new wiring, using the good old copper phone lines.

Digital Video Recording (DVR) technology is a game-changer in how we watch and record TV. It lets you save shows on a hard drive, pause live TV, and skip commercials. DVRs are essential in modern home entertainment, offering high-quality recordings and the convenience of watching your favorite shows whenever you want.

C is a versatile, procedural programming language, born in the early 1970s at Bell Labs. It's the foundation for system software like operating systems and device drivers. C gives programmers direct control over hardware and efficient memory management, making it ideal for tasks that need close hardware interaction.

C# (pronounced 'C sharp') is a modern language from Microsoft, crucial for the .NET platform. Released in 2002, it's become a go-to for desktop, web, and mobile apps. C# is strongly typed, supporting various programming styles, and works seamlessly with .NET's extensive library, simplifying coding and speeding up app development.

C++ is an evolution of C, adding object-oriented features to the mix. Born in the 1980s, it's ideal for a range of applications - from system software to games. C++'s compiled nature ensures fast execution, and its support for object-oriented programming makes it great for creating complex applications with reusable code.

C++ has been a programming favorite for over 30 years, favored for its speed and resource efficiency. It's ideal for fast-executing apps and complex systems. C++ excels in object-oriented programming, making it great for large-scale software. Its widespread use, comprehensive libraries, and supportive community keep it at the forefront of programming languages.

Cache is like a memory shortcut, storing frequently used data for quick access. When a program needs data, the computer first looks in the cache, speeding up the process. It's found everywhere - in processors, hard drives, and browsers, either as a hardware feature or a software function, boosting overall system performance.

Imagine your computer's CPU as a chef working in a kitchen. The CPU cache is like a small, speedy countertop where the chef keeps the ingredients he uses most often. This way, he doesn't have to walk to the fridge (the main memory) every time, saving a lot of time and effort. When a program needs data, the CPU checks the countertop first before heading to the fridge, making everything faster and smoother.

Disk Cache: Think of disk cache as a memory shortcut in your computer. When you open a file, your computer remembers it in a faster storage area. Next time you need that file, your computer grabs it quickly from this quick-access storage, rather than taking longer to fetch it from the main storage. It's like keeping your favorite book on your desk instead of the bookshelf, so it's always at hand.

Network cache is like a local storage locker for internet data. When you visit a website, some of its data is stored nearby, so the next time you visit, your computer can grab it from this local 'locker' instead of fetching it all the way from the website's server. It's like keeping a copy of a frequently read newspaper at your doorstep instead of walking to the store every day.

Electronic calculators are the pocket-sized wizards of math. They took over from their slower, bulkier predecessors, the mechanical calculators, in the 1960s. With just a few taps on their buttons, they can solve complex equations in a blink, making life easier for everyone from students to scientists. They're like reliable math buddies, always ready to tackle numbers.

Cars today are like computers on wheels, thanks to the magic of computing. From managing engines for better performance to turning them into entertainment hubs with infotainment systems, computing has revolutionized driving. It's also paving the way for self-driving cars, which use sensors and algorithms to navigate roads. Even car safety got a tech upgrade, with systems to prevent accidents and protect passengers.

Smart cars are like smartphones – but for the road. They're equipped with technology that makes driving safer and more convenient. Features like lane-keeping and automatic braking help prevent accidents. They're also connected to the internet, so they can get real-time traffic updates and even update their software on the go. Some can even drive themselves, thanks to advanced sensors and computing power.

CSS is the fashion designer of the web page world. It decides how a web page should look, from the font style to the background color. It works with HTML, the web's basic structure, to give websites their unique style and flair. CSS is like the wardrobe stylist for web pages, making sure they look their best.

Computer-aided software engineering (CASE) tools are like the Swiss Army knives for software developers. They help in designing, coding, testing, and maintaining software. Imagine having a toolbox that helps you from the initial sketch of a building to its final construction - that's what CASE tools do for software development.

Design tools are the paintbrushes and canvases for digital artists and designers. Whether it's creating stunning graphics, modeling 3D worlds, animating videos, or crafting website layouts, these tools turn creative ideas into digital reality. They're the essential companions for anyone wanting to bring their artistic visions to life on a screen.

Analysis tools in computing are like magnifying glasses for data. They help businesses and researchers examine large amounts of data to uncover hidden patterns and insights. Whether it's predicting market trends, visualizing complex data, or making sense of customer feedback, these tools are vital for making informed, data-driven decisions.

A CD-ROM is like a digital book that stores up to 700 MB of data, equivalent to an 80-minute audio recording. Introduced in 1985, it became a popular way to distribute software and digital content due to its portability and wide compatibility with different devices.

CD-Rs are like reusable notebooks for digital data. Unlike the fixed content of CD-ROMs, you can 'write' or record your own data on a CD-R, whether it's backing up important files, storing photos, or creating music CDs. They are like blank pages waiting for your personal data story.

DVD-ROMs are like the bigger cousins of CD-ROMs, holding much more data - up to 8.5 GB. This makes them perfect for storing large files like movies and software. They're widely used for commercial media distribution and are compatible with most DVD players and computer drives.

Cellular automata are like digital LEGO blocks that can simulate complex systems. They're used in various fields, from modeling physical phenomena to exploring biological patterns. These mathematical models show how simple rules can lead to complex behaviors, making them a fascinating tool for research and art alike.

nternet censorship is like having a big filter over what you can see and share online. Governments or companies use it to block or limit access to certain information or websites. While some argue it's necessary for security or decency, others see it as a threat to free speech and information access.

CGI is the art of creating visual content using computers. It's like digital magic that brings to life everything from realistic dinosaurs in movies to stunning landscapes in video games. CGI blends technology and art to create amazing visuals that captivate and astonish.

In programming, a character is like a single letter, while a string is like a word or sentence made up of these letters. Characters are the basic building blocks of text in programming, and strings are sequences of these characters that we use to represent words, phrases, or any text.

String-oriented programming languages are like specialized tools for handling text. They make it easier for programmers to work with strings - be it slicing, dicing, or modifying text. Languages like Perl, Python, Ruby, and JavaScript offer powerful features to play around with words and sentences in the coding world.

In the computing world, commercial services are like the various shops in a mall, each offering a specific type of product or service. From cloud computing and software applications to IT support and web hosting, these services cater to different needs, helping businesses run smoothly in the digital space.

Distributed services in computing are like a team of workers spread across different locations, each handling a part of a big project. This setup boosts efficiency, reliability, and scalability. It's used in various applications like distributed databases, computing frameworks, and web services, making large-scale and complex operations manageable.

Chatterbots, or chatbots, are like virtual assistants who can chat with you. They use AI to understand and respond to messages, helping with customer service, providing information, or just having a friendly conversation. They're the digital buddies who are always ready to chat and assist.

Chess has been a playground for testing AI's brainpower. It's a game of strategy and foresight, posing a unique challenge for computers. Over the years, AI has evolved to not only play chess but also outsmart human champions, showcasing its growing intelligence and problem-solving abilities.

Chess has been a critical testing ground for AI. The game's complexity offers a perfect challenge for pushing the limits of AI algorithms. From evaluating billions of potential moves to learning optimal strategies, AI development in chess has been a journey of mastering one of the most intellectually demanding games.

A chipset in a computer acts like a traffic director, managing the data flow between the processor and other key components. It's divided into two parts: the northbridge and southbridge, each handling different tasks to ensure your computer runs efficiently. Think of it as the control center of your computer's operations.

The "last mile" in telecommunications is the final stretch connecting users to the broader network. It's a crucial link, like the last piece of a puzzle, ensuring that homes and businesses have access to telecommunication services. The challenge lies in physically connecting each location, especially in remote areas.

In object-oriented programming, a class is like a blueprint for creating objects. It defines what features (properties) and behaviors (methods) these objects will have. You can think of it as a recipe that details the ingredients and steps to make a particular dish, where the dish is the object.

Client-server computing is like a restaurant where clients are customers ordering food (data or services) and the server is the kitchen fulfilling those orders. This model efficiently handles multiple requests, allowing centralized control and resource management in computing environments.

Client-server computing offers centralized control, scalability, resource sharing, improved performance, and platform independence. It's like having a central library where everyone can access books (resources) efficiently, and it's always updating and expanding its collection.
Clock speed in CPUs is like the heartbeat of a computer. Measured in GHz, it tells you how many operations the CPU can perform in a second. A faster clock speed means the CPU can

COBOL, a high-level programming language, has been a cornerstone in the world of business applications since 1959. Renowned for its user-friendly design, it caters to both programmers and business professionals alike. Its robust data processing capabilities make it ideal for industries like banking, insurance, and government, handling large data volumes with ease. While primarily run on mainframes, COBOL has evolved to operate on platforms like Windows and Unix. Despite its vintage, COBOL's reliability in managing substantial data keeps it relevant and widely used, with billions of lines of code active today.

A codec, standing for 'coder-decoder,' plays a crucial role in digital media by compressing and decompressing audio and video files. Its goal is to minimize file size without compromising quality. Two types of codecs exist: lossy and lossless. Lossy codecs shrink file size by sacrificing some original data, affecting quality, whereas lossless codecs retain all data, ensuring no quality loss. Common in streaming, video conferencing, and digital media playback, codecs like H.264 (video) and MP3 (audio) are vital. Whether proprietary or open-source, the right codec is essential for media playback or editing.

Cognitive science, an amalgamation of psychology, neuroscience, linguistics, philosophy, computer science, and anthropology, delves into the intricacies of human thought. This field explores how we perceive, remember, communicate, and make decisions. Through experiments and modeling, it seeks answers to profound questions about sensory interpretation, knowledge acquisition, reasoning, and language use. Its findings have profound implications in education, artificial intelligence, and human-computer interaction, offering a window into the human mind's complex workings.

In computing, color representation hinges on the RGB (Red, Green, Blue) model. This model, rooted in additive color theory, creates varied hues by mixing red, green, and blue light in varying intensities. Each pixel on a screen consists of these three subpixels, with their intensity determining the pixel's color. While RGB is predominant in digital displays, other models like CMYK for printing and HSL/HSV for graphic design are also crucial. Colors greatly influence the design and user experience of websites and applications, playing a key role in conveying mood and highlighting information.

The RGB color model, harnessing the primary colors of light - Red, Green, and Blue, is fundamental in creating a spectrum of colors through additive color theory. By adjusting the intensity of these three colors, from no intensity (0) to maximum (255), it's possible to generate an astounding 16.7 million colors. This model's versatility and range make it a staple in digital color representation.

In printing, the CMYK color model reigns supreme, combining Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, and Key (Black) to produce a vast array of colors. Operating on subtractive color theory, it achieves color creation by varying the ink intensity on white paper. Full intensity of all colors results in black, representing the model's ability to absorb all light. Each color in CMYK is represented by a percentage, ranging from no ink (0%) to full coverage (100%), allowing for a wide spectrum of printable colors.

A 'palette' can signify different things in various contexts. In art, it's the flat surface used by painters to mix colors before application. It also refers to the specific color range an artist chooses for their work. In design and computer graphics, a palette is a pre-defined set of colors for a project, ensuring consistency and visual appeal. These palettes, crucial for cohesive design, can be manually created or generated by software tools.

Probability quantifies the likelihood of an event's occurrence. Represented as a number between 0 (impossible) and 1 (certain), it's calculated by dividing the favorable outcomes by the total possible outcomes. For example, flipping a coin has a probability of 0.5 for heads, considering two possible outcomes. Probability theory, integral in various fields like statistics and engineering, helps model and analyze systems involving randomness or uncertainty.

A compiler is a vital tool in software development, translating human-readable source code into machine-executable code. It not only converts syntax and structure but also optimizes the code for better performance. By enabling developers to code in high-level languages, compilers bridge the gap between abstract programming and specific hardware requirements. They play a crucial role in error detection and code optimization, making them indispensable in creating efficient and error-free software.

The compilation process involves several stages, transforming programming language code into executable machine code. It starts with lexical analysis, identifying code tokens, followed by syntax analysis to check language rules. Semantic analysis ensures logical correctness, leading to machine code generation. The compiler optimizes this code for performance and size. Each stage, from interpreting tokens to generating efficient machine code, is critical in creating functional, optimized software.

NLP is a multidisciplinary field that draws from linguistics and computer science, particularly artificial intelligence ,.  In terms of linguistics, a program must be able to deal with words that have multiple meanings (“wind up the clock” and “the wind is cold today”) as well as grammatical ambiguities (in the phrase “little girl’s school” is it the school that is little, the girls, or both?).  Of course each language has its own forms of ambiguity. Programs can use several strategies for dealing with these problems, including using statistical models to predict the likely meaning of a given phrase based on a “corpus” of existing text in that language ,. As formidable as the task of extracting the correct (literal) meaning from text can be, it is really only the first level of natural language processing.  If a program is to successfully summarize or draw conclusions about a news report from North Korea, for example, it would also have to have a knowledge base of facts about that country and/or a set of “frames” , about how to interpret various situations such as threat, bluff, or compromise. )

There are a variety of emerging applications for NLP, including the following:, voice-controlled computer interfaces (such as in aircraft cockpits), programs that can assist with planning or other tasks ,, more-realistic interactions with computer-controlled game characters, robots that interact with humans in various settings such as hospitals, automatic analysis or summarization of news stories and other text, intelligence and surveillance applications (analysis of communication, etc. ), data mining, creating consumer profiles, and other ecommerce applications, search-engine improvements, such as in determining relevancy

As each new means of communication and social interaction is introduced, social customs and etiquette evolve in response.  For example, it took time before the practice of saying “hello” and identifying oneself became the universal way to initiate a phone conversation. By the 1980s, a system of topical news postings , carried on the Internet was becoming widely used in universities, the computer industry, and scientific institutions.  Many new users did not understand the system, and posted messages that were off topic.  Others used their postings as to insult or attack (“flame”) other users, particularly in newsgroups discussing perennially controversial topics such as abortion.  When a significant number of postings in a newsgroup are devoted to flaming and counter-flaming, many users who had sought civilized, intelligent discussion leave in protest. In 1984, Chuq von Rospach wrote a document entitled “A Primer on How to Work with the Usenet Community. ” It and later guides to net etiquette or “netiquette” offered useful guidelines to new users and to more experienced users who wanted to facilitate civil discourse.

These suggestions include:, Learn about the purpose of a newsgroup before you post to it.  If a group is moderated, understand the moderator’s guidelines so your postings won’t be rejected. , Before posting, follow some discussions to see what sort of language, tone, and attitude seems to be appropriate for this group Do not post bulky graphics or other attachments unless the group is designed for them. , Avoid “ad hominem” (to the person) attacks when discussing disagreements. , Do not post in ALL CAPS, which is interpreted as “shouting. ”, Check your postings for proper spelling and grammar.  On the other hand, avoid “flaming” other users for their spelling or grammar errors. , When replying to an existing message, include enough of the original message to provide context for your reply, but no more. , If you know the answer to a question or problem raised by another user, send it to that user by e-mail.  That way the newsgroup doesn’t get cluttered up with dozens of versions of the same information.

In recent years there has been growing concern that Internet users may eventually be treated differently by service providers depending on the kind of data they download or the kind of application programs they use online.  Advocates of network (or net) neutrality , want legislation that would bar cable, DSL, or other providers , from making such distinctions, such as by charging content providers higher fees for high volumes of data or even blocking certain applications.  Advocates of net neutrality believe that, since there are rather limited choices for broadband Internet service, discrimination on the basis of Web content could lead to a loss of freedom for consumers and providers alike

By the late 1970s, researchers at many major universities were using the UNIX operating system ,.  In 1979, a suite of utilities called UUCP was distributed with the widely used UNIX Version 7.  These utilities could be used to transfer files between UNIX computers that were linked by some form of telephone or network connection. Two Duke University graduate students, Tom Truscott and Jim Ellis, decided to set up a way in which users on different computers could share a collection of files containing text messages on various topics.  They wrote a simple set of shell scripts that could be used for distributing and viewing these message files.  The first version of the news network linked computers at Duke and at the University of North Carolina.  Soon these programs were revised and rewritten in the C language and distributed to other UNIX users as the “A” release of the News software. During the 1980s, the news system was expanded and features such as moderated newsgroups were added.  As the Internet and its TCP/IP protocol , became a more widespread standard for connecting computers, a version of News using the NNTP (Network News Transmission Protocol) over the Internet was released in 1986.  Netnews is a mature system today, with news reading software available for virtually every type of computer

Netnews postings are simply text files that begin with a set of standard headers, similar to those used in e-mail.  (Like e-mail, news postings can have binary graphics or program files attached, using a standard called MIME, for Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions. )The files are stored on news servers—machines that have the spare capacity to handle the hundreds of gigabytes of messages now posted each week.  The files are stored in a typical hierarchical UNIX fashion, grouped into approximately 75,000 different newsgroups. As shown in the following table, the newsgroups are broken down into 10 major categories.  The names of individual groups begin with the major category and then specify subdivisions.  For example, the newsgroup comp. sys. ibm. pc deals with IBM PC-compatible personal computers, while comp. os. linux deals with the Linux operating system.

The servers are linked into a branching distribution system.  Messages being posted by users are forwarded to the nearest major regional “node” site, which in turn distributes them to other major nodes.  In turn, when messages arrive at a major node from another region, they are distributed to all the smaller sites that share the newsfeed.  Due to the volume of groups and messages, many sites now choose to receive only a subset of the total newsfeed.  Sites also determine when messages will expire (and thus be removed from the site). There are dozens of different news reading programs that can be used to view the available newsgroups and postings.  On UNIX systems, programs such as elm and tin are popular, while other newsreaders cater to Windows, Macintosh, and other systems.  Major Web browsers such as Netscape and Internet Explorer offer simplified news reading features.  To use these news readers, the user accesses a newsfeed at an address provided by the Internet Service Provider (ISP).  There are also services that let users simply navigate through the news system by following the links on a Web page.  The former service called DejaNews, now Google Groups, is the best-known and most complete such site

In the 1940s, the main objective in developing the first digital computers was to speed up the process of calculation.  In the 1950s, the machines began to be used for more general data-processing tasks by governments and business.  By the 1960s, computers were in use in most major academic, government, and business organizations.  The desire for users to share data and to communicate both within and outside their organization led to efforts to link computers together into networks. Computer manufacturers began to develop proprietary networking software to link their computers, but they were limited to a particular kind of computer, such as a DEC PDP minicomputer, or an IBM mainframe.  However, the U. S.  Defense Department, seeing the need for a robust, decentralized network that could maintain links between their computers under wartime conditions, funded the development of a protocol that, given appropriate hardware to bridge the gap, could link these disparate networks ,.

According to the OSI (open systems interconnection) model, a network can be considered to be a series of seven layers laid one atop another ,. The physical layer is at the bottom.  It specifies the physical connections between the computers, which can be anything from ordinary phone lines to cable, fiber optic, or wireless.  This layer specifies the required electrical characteristics (such as voltage changes and durations that constitute the physical signal that is recognized as either a 1 or 0 in the “bit stream. ”The next layer, called the data link layer, specifies how data will be grouped into chunks of bits (frames or packets) and how transmission errors will be dealt with ,. The network layer groups the data frames as parts of a properly formed data packet and routes that packet from the sending node to the specified destination node.  A variety of routing algorithms can be used to determine the most efficient route given current traffic or line conditions. The transport layer views the packets as part of a complete transmission of an object (such as a Web page) and ensures that all the packets belonging to that object are sorted into their original sequence at the destination.  This is necessary because packets belonging to the same message may be sent via different routes in keeping with traffic or line conditions. The session layer provides application programs communicating over the network with the ability to initiate, terminate, or restart an interrupted data transfer. The presentation layer ensures that data formats are consistent so that all applications know what to expect.  This layer can also provide special services ,. Finally, the application layer gives applications highlevel commands for performing tasks over the network, such as file transfer protocol (ftp)

A network attached storage (NAS) unit can be thought of as a dedicated data storage unit that is available to all users of a network.  Unlike a traditional dedicated file storage unit ,, a NAS unit typically has an operating system and software designed specifically (and only) for providing data storage services.  The actual storage is usually provided by an array of hard drives ,.  Files on the NAS are accessed through protocols such as SMB (server message block), common on Windows networks, and NFS (network file system), used on many UNIX and some Linux networks.  In recent years smaller, lower-cost NAS devices have become available for smaller networks, including home networks, where they can store music, video, and other files ,

Although it sounds similar, a storage area network (SAN) does not function as its own file server.  Rather, it attaches storage modules such as hard drives or tape libraries to an existing server so that it appears to the server’s operating system as though it were locally attached.  Typically the protocol used to attach the storage is SCSI ,, but the physical connection is fiber or high-speed Ethernet.  The emphasis for SAN applications is the need for fast access to data, such as in large online databases, e-mail servers, and high-volume file servers.  SANs offer great flexibility, since storage can be expanded without changing the network structure, and a replacement server can quickly be attached to the storage in case of hardware failure

In the kind of science fiction sometimes called “cyberpunk,”people are able to “jack in” or connect their brains directly tocomputer networks.  Because of this direct input into the brain(or perhaps the optic and other sensory nerves), a personwho is jacked in experiences the virtual world as fully real,and can (depending on the world’s rules) manipulate it withhis or her mind.  This kind of all-immersive virtual reality isstill science fiction, but today people are beginning to controlcomputers and artificial limbs directly with their minds.

Neuroprosthetics is the creation of artificial limbs or sensoryorgans that are directly connected to the nervous system. The first (and most widely used) example is the cochlearimplant, which can restore hearing by taking sound signals from a microphone and converting them to electricalimpulses that directly stimulate auditory nerves within thecochlea, a part of the inner ear.  Similarly, experimental retinal implants that stimulate optic nerves are beginning tooffer crude but useful vision to certain blind patients. Research in connecting the brain to artificial arms orlegs is still in its early stages, but scientists using microelectrode arrays have been able to record signals from thebrain’s neurons and correlate them to different types ofmotor movements.  In a series of experiments at Duke University, researchers first trained a monkey to operate a joystick to move a shape in a video game.  They then recordedand analyzed the signals produced by the monkey’s brainwhile playing the game, and correlated them with themotor movements in the joystick.  Next, they replicatedthese movements with a robotic arm as the monkey movedthe joystick.  Finally, they were able to train the monkey tomove the robotic arm without using the joystick at all, simply by “thinking” about the movements.

As more is learned about the detailed functioning of neuronal networks inside the brain, “cognitive prosthetics” maybecome feasible.  One example might be computer memory modules that might act as a surrogate or extension ofhuman memory, perhaps helping compensate for loss ofmemory due to age or disease.  (Early experiments on interfacing to the hippocampus, a part of the brain important forforming memories, have been underway since 2003. )Other possibilities might include processors that couldgive a person the ability to think about a mathematicalproblem and “see” the answer, or to search databases or theWeb simply by visualizing or thinking about the information desired

Integers (whole numbers) have the simplest representation, but there are two important considerations: the totalnumber of bits available and whether one bit is used to holdthe sign. Since all numbers are stored as binary digits, an unsignedinteger has a range from 0 to 2bits where “bits” is the totalnumber of bits available.  Thus if there are 16 bits available, the maximum value for an integer is 65535.  If negativenumbers are to be handled, a signed integer must be used(in most languages such as C, C++, and Java, an integer issigned unless unsigned is specified).  Since one bit is usedto hold the sign and each bit doubles the maximum size, itfollows that a signed integer can have only half the rangeabove or below zero.  Thus, a 16-bit signed integer can rangefrom -32,768 to 32,767. One complication is that the available sizes of integersdepend on whether the computer system’s native data sizeis 16, 32, or 64 bits.  In most cases the native size is 32 bits,so the declaration “int” in a C program on such a machineimplies a signed 32-bit integer that can range from - 231 or-2,147,483,647 to 231-1, or 2,147,483,647.  However, if one isusing large numbers in a program, it is important to checkthat the chosen type is large enough.  The long specifier isoften used to indicate an integer twice the normal size, or64 bits in this case.

Numbers with a fractional (decimal) part are usually storedin a format called floating point.  The “floating” means thatthe location of the decimal point can be moved as necessaryto fit the number within the specified digit range.  A floatingpoint number is actually stored in four separate parts.  Firstcomes the sign, indicating whether the number is negativeor positive.  Next comes the mantissa, which contains theactual digits of the number, both before and after the decimal point.  The radix is the “base” for the number systemused.  Finally, the exponent determines where the decimalpoint will be placed. For example, the base 10 number 247. 35 could be represented as 24735 × 10-2.  The -2 moves the decimal pointat the end two places to the left.  However, floating-pointnumbers are normalized to a form in which there is just onedigit to the left of the decimal point.  Thus, 247. 35 wouldactually be written 2. 4735 × 102.  This system is also knownas scientific notation. As noted earlier, actual data storage in modern computers is always in binary, but the same principle applies. According to IEEE Standard 754, 32-bit floating-point numbers use 1 bit for the sign, 8 bits for the exponent, and 23bits for the mantissa (also called the significand, since itexpressed the digits that are significant—that is, guaranteed not to be “lost” through overflow or underflow in processing).  The double precision float, declared as a “double”in C programs, uses 1, 11, and 52 bits respectively.

Many objects are more elaborate or specialized variations ofmore basic objects.  For example, in Microsoft Windows thevarious kinds of dialog boxes are specialized versions of thegeneral Window class.  Therefore, the specialized versionis created by declaring it to be derived from a “base class. ”Put another way, the specialized class inherits the basicdata and functions available in the base (parent) class.  Theprogrammer can then add new data or functions or modifythe inherited ones to create the necessary behavior for thespecialized class. Languages such as C++ allow for a class to be derivedfrom more than one base class.  This is called multipleinheritance.  For example, a Message Window class mightinherit its overall structure from the Window class andits text-display capabilities from the Message class.  However, it can sometimes be difficult to keep the relationshipsbetween multiple classes clear.  The Java language takes thealternative approach of being limited to only single inheritance of classes, but allowing interfaces (specifications ofhow a class interacts with the program) to be multiplyinherited.

Different kinds of objects often have analogous methods. For example, suppose there is a series of classes that represent various polygons: square, triangle, hexagon, and so forth.  Each class has a method called “perimeter” thatreturns the total distance around the edges of the object.  Ifeach of these classes is derived from a base polygon class,each class inherits the base class’s perimeter method andadapts it for its own use.  Thus, a square might calculateits perimeter simply by multiplying the length of a side byfour, while the rectangle would have to add up differentsized pairs of sides, and so on.

In the late 1990s “banner ads” started to appear on Websites, and other forms of advertising soon followed.  Companies rushed into the online world, either with the belief thatit had unlimited potential for finding new customers, or outof fear that the competition would get there first.  Unfortunately it was hard to measure the actual effectiveness ofads, and Web sites (such as for publications) that lookedto third-party advertising as a source of income found theoutlook bleak in the wake of the bursting of the “dot-combubble” of the early 2000 decade. Only a few years later, however, advertisers using newbusiness models and targeting techniques have made onlineadvertising not only a viable business, but a rapidly growing one.  (According to the Interactive Advertsing Bureau,Internet advertising revenue in the United States in 2007was $21. 2 billion, up 26 percent from 2005. )The effects of the online advertising revolution are rippling outward, impacting traditional advertising mediasuch as newspapers (in particular see craigslist), magazines, and even television.

Types of ads include the following:, Banner ads are contained in rectangles, often at the topof the Web page.  (Sometimes they can mimic dialogboxes from the operating system. ) They still accountfor about half of all online advertising, and can appearon sites of all types. , Pop-up or pop-under ads appear above or beneath thecurrent window, respectivelyFloating ads appear over the main page content, oftenmoving across the screen. , Interstitial ads are displayed before the requestedcontent (such as an article or video) is shown.  Theyrun for a specified period of time, although they cansometimes be closed by the viewer. Many ads are animated; some even contain video clips. There are also ads formatted for mobile devices, includingtext messages sent to cell phones.

Google and other large search enginesor portals can make money from advertisers is through“affiliate marketing”; Google’s version is called Ad Sense. Participating Web sites are indexed, and the resulting keywords are matched with ads awaiting placement.  The sitecarrying the ad generally gets a per-click payment.  However, the problem of “click fraud” has also arisen: Scammerscan set up an affiliate site and then use special software togenerate the clicks, while making them come from a varietyof sources.  Despite these problems, in 2006 about 40 percent of revenue from online advertising was attributed tosearch-related ads.

The dark side of online advertising is found in programsthat are surreptitiously installed on users’ PCs and thendownload and display advertising from shady Web operations ,.  While many users nowregularly run programs to block such malware, even legitimate online advertising can irritate users, particularlywhen ads are too prominent, float over (and block) text, orlurk behind the browser window.  Modern Web browsershave ad-blocking features that work with varying degreesof effectiveness.  As with TV, online advertisers increasinglyhave to cope with impatient users who do not have to lookat ads unless they actually want to. Advertisers can employ several strategies to keep userswilling to look at ads.  One is to make the ad unobtrusiveand brief, and on the way to something the user reallywants to see.  In 2007 YouTube began such advertising. Another is to provide free versions of software or servicesthat, in exchange for being free, require the user to put upwith some screen real estate being devoted to ads.  Finally,as with TV, advertising can be woven into the content itself,such as in online computer games. A sensitive area is the attempt to balance advertisers’desire to know as much as possible about consumers’ interestsand buying habits with the same consumers’ concern aboutprotecting their privacy
